Key.Original: The AH-1 Navajo is an attack helicopter based on the AH-64 Apache produced under license by Italy. However, in the aftermath of the economic shocks of the 2020s, much of the military equipment of European nations such as Italy was sold off or dismantled in austerity measures. Thus, the AH-1 Navajo is somewhat commonly seen being operated by second-hand owners, who purchased the vehicles at low prices.

Key.Original: The F-35F Peregrine is a fifth-generation, single-seat, single-engine, all-weather, stealth multi-role aircraft. Development started in the early 21st century by a consortium of Western aircraft and avionics manufacturers. Despite controversy over the development of the aircraft and an incredibly high development cost, it emerged a combat-capable aircraft available at relativly low costs, and as such was adopted by numerous countries to replace previous generation fighters. It exists in a variety of models, and the F-35F particularly is fitted with the necessary equipment for carrier operations, and includes a datalink to interface with friendly units in the field. It is also capable of mounting external pylons to further increase its payload, at a detriment to its stealth capability.

Key.Original: The C-192 Samson is an updated successor to the American C-130 designed for export. Though outdated compared to its modern counterparts, its four-engine turbo-prop design allows it to transport a variety of cargo, or up to 52 passengers, with a range of over 5,000 km at a maximum speed of 650 kph. It has become a common sight among military organizations throughout the world - including CSAT, which produces its own copy, labeled the Iran-150. A civilian variant, the L-192, sees widespread usage with various airlines, logistics companies, and NGOs where it is valued as a rugged, dependable cargo aircraft.

Key.Original: Based on a South African upgrade package for the venerable Mi-24 airframe, the Mi-35 Krokodil (or 'Superhind') represents a significant boost in capability for the hybrid gunship/troop transport. The aircraft contains improved avionics, sensors, and an upgraded engine to help it compete in conflicts of the 2030's. The airframe hosts a formidable arsenal, armed with a 20mm cannon loading both HE and APDS rounds, as well as six pylons to mount extra ordinance. The Mi-35 sees use all around the globe, either in the form of upgraded Mi-24s, or as license-build bespoke productions from a variety of manufacturers, including a joint-South African/Chernarusian venture.

The aircraft contains improved avionics, sensors, and an upgraded engine to help it compete in conflicts of the 2030's. Key.Original: The IFV-6c Panther is based on the Isreali Nemmera APC, licensed and produced in the United States in vast numbers to replace both the M2 Bradley line of IFVs, and the aged M113 line of APCs. With the APC based on the M2 Slammer tank chassis, it is one of the most heavily armored vehicles in the world, able to take several IED, rocket, and ATGM rounds. Thus, the vehicle endeared itself on Western militaries, mired in counterinsurgency operations around the globe.

Key.Original: Based on a South African design, the AMV-7 Marshall serves US forces as a replacement for both the Stryker line of vehicles, as well as the aging LAV line. Heavily armed with a 30mm autocannon, the vehicle is light enough to be transported via V-44 X Blackfish, granting it an incredible level of strategic mobility. The lack of any built-in ATGMs is intentional to reduce the footprint of the vehicle, and the capability is made up for when paired with its sister vehicle, the Rhino MGS.

Key.Original: First field trialed by the Russian Army in 2009, the BTR-90 ultimately failed to enter military service. However plans to adopt an upgraded variant surfaced in the 2020s, labeled BTR-100 with the nickname "Bogatyr". This enhanced package introduces a remote turret alongside numerous improvements to the vehicle's survivability, armaments, and handling. Its fitted with a 30 mm cannon, coaxial machine gun, and 9M135 Vorona ATGMs improving its effectiveness against armored targets. The BTR-100's 8x8, all-wheel-drive, amphibious design is favored by motorized infantry, but - compared to its Western counterparts - the vehicle itself is rather outdated.

Key.Original: The BRDM-K Nosorog was initially designed as an unmanned autonomous drone, but - after an incident involving the Nosorog's hunter-killer system and a goat - engineers decided a traditional crew would be more reliable and effective. Technically a tank destroyer, the BRDM-K is used for reconnaissance, fire support, and hit-and-run tactics. Its remote turret is equipped with a 125 mm cannon and a coaxial machine gun. Due to the added weight, the BRDM-K loses its amphibious capability, and its transport compartment is used to store ammunition.

Technically a tank destroyer, the BRDM-K is used for reconnaissance, fire support, and hit-and-run tactics. Its remote turret is equipped with a 125 mm cannon and a coaxial machine gun. Due to the added weight, the BRDM-K loses its amphibious capability, and its transport compartment is used to store ammunition.

Key.Original: The Samovila cabin cruiser was built by the hundreds by Zelene Mora Verfi in Chernarus. It is a cheap and simple, yet sturdy design, which was marketed as a suitable private boat for both families and fishing enthusiasts. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the company attempted to export their boat on the global market with great success, and the Samovila has become a common sight on waterways and along shores all over the world.

Key.Original: Arma 3 Aegis aims to expand on the vanilla 2035 setting directly with a variety of new weapons, factions, vehicles, and equipment. Many items have been readded from the pre-Alpha, with a focus on bringing them up to the same level of quality and consistency as other vanilla items. Aegis also enhances the vanilla sandbox by improving vanilla faction's loadouts and visuals.

Key.Original:
Formed at the apex of the Canton Protocol summits in the 2020's, this strategic alliance of states is built upon the goals of mutual defense, expanded global influence, and sustained economic growth.
Set against the context of foundering economies and civil unrest across the west, CSAT has risen in prominence over the last decade. Investment in shared civil and military technology and the aggressive pursuit of opportunities and partnerships throughout Asia, South America and North Africa has led to a sharp increase in strategic tension across the globe, as traditional spheres of power and influence are encroached upon. Key member states of CSAT include the founding members China and Iran, as well as auxilliary member states; such as Argana, Belarus, Takistan, and Venezuela. Military deployments conducted by CSAT superceed the member states military command, organizing troops into Regiments. Examples of these include Iran's Griffin Regiment, China's Tarantula Regiment, Takistan's Scorpion Regiment, Belarus' Bear Regiment, and Venezuela's Jaguar Regiment.

Key.Original: The M32 is a lightweight 40 mm semi-automatic, 6-shot grenade launcher. It is intended to increase a small squad's firepower when compared to traditional single-shot underslung grenade launchers.

Key.Original: The M200 is a gas-operated, belt-fed light machine gun originating from the United States, featuring an ergonomic design with a reinforced lock and a quick barrel removal system. It fires 6.5x39 mm caseless ammunition with a rate of 800 rounds per minute. The M200 provies squads with the accurate and sustained fire-power required to suppress and destroy enemy targets.

Key.Original: The G17 is a short recoil-operated, locked-breech semi-automatic pistol chambered in 9 mm that was first developed in 1982 to replace the obsolescent P38 pistol in use by the Austrian army. Simplicity of operation combined with having a minimum number of parts as well as a polymer design has made it a highly popular weapon, with many armies and police forces throughout the world using it.

Key.Original: The SR-1M, also known as the Gyurza, is a 9 mm DA/SA, short recoil operated semi-automatic pistol, inspired by the Beretta 92, that was designed in the 1990s for the Russian military. Although they initially rejected it, a revised version with better ergonomics was later selected for usage by the FSB, FSO and Spetsnaz. To this day, it remains the favoured pistol of Russian SF, and has found its way into the hands of a variety of militaries and police forces around the world.

Key.Original: Despite its poor reputation and troubled reception in the past, the SA80 remains as the main service rifle for the British Armed Forces. The L85A3 has been rechambered for NATO's standardized 6.5x39 mm caseless ammunition, and features a new full-length rail enabling modularity and variety of other changes to improve the reliability and stability of the weapon. It is often issued with a grip-pod, but can be fitted with a 40 mm underslung grenade launcher. A compact carbine variant with a shortened barrel exists and is labelled the L22A3.

Key.Original: The Mk17 entered service during Operation Arrowhead, and while its lighter counterpart was eventually replaced by the MX, it remains in use with US special forces. It's a reliable battle rifle originating from Belgium, with a modular design that is compatible with a variety of accessories. Chambered for 7.62x51 mm ammunition, it hits harder than most assault rifles at the cost of increased weight and reduced magazine capacity. It can be fitted with a 40 mm underslung grenade launcher or an underbarrel 12 gauge shotgun module. A shortened version exists, labelled the Mk17C.

Key.Original: The Mk16 first saw service during operations in Takistan in 2012, after which it saw roughly a decade of service as the primary assault rifle of the US army before being replaced by the MX series when the decision was made to move to the more powerful 6.5x39 mm round. Nonetheless, it remains a reliable assault rifle with a modular design that is compatible with a variety of accessories, features that have seen it widely exported. Produced in Belgium, it is chambered for 5.56x45 mm ammunition and can accept any magazine in a STANAG configuration, making it popular across the globe. It can be fitted with a 40 mm underslung grenade launcher or an under-barrel 12 gauge shotgun module. A shortened version exists, labelled the Mk16C.

Key.Original: The AK-74 is an assault rifle designed by Mikhail Kalashnikov in the 1970s, chambered in the 5.45 x 39 mm round that replaced the 7.62 x 39 mm used in earlier rifles. The rifle first saw service in the Soviet-Afghan war, and remains widely used across the world in the hands of militaries and insurgents both, and in a variety of license-produced forms.

Key.Original: The M4A1 is a gas-operated, magazine fed 5.56 mm carbine developed by the United States in the 1980s, as a shortened variation of the M16 assault rifle, before superceding its parent weapon as the US' main assault rifle. Although the US started to phase it out in the 2010s in favour of the Mk16, and later the MX, family of rifles, the M4A1 has seen widespread adoption around the world, leading to it being described as one of the defining firearms of the 21st century. There are a huge number of variants and licensed production versions of the rifle available, and it remains a capable and reliable 5.56 mm platform even in the complex battlespaces of the 2030s, commonly seen sporting some form of grenade launcher, or in short-barrelled variations to increase lethality and handling in close quarters combat.

Key.Original: The Mk11 is a designated marksman rifle derived from the AR-10, rechambered in 7.62x51 mm and using a rotating bolt system. More than half of the parts of the rifle are interchangeable with the AR-15 and M16 families, which has made the Mk11 a popular choice due to the relative ease of operation and maintenance. The US army used a variant, designated the M110, alongside the Mk16 - where it notably saw service in Takistan during Operation Arrowhead - before phasing it out in favour of the MXM when the decision was made to switch to the more versatile 6.5x39 mm round. Nevertheless, the Mk11 and M110 continues to see use in militaries that prefer the more traditional 7.62 round.

Key.Original: The AA-40 is a shotgun capable of a fully automatic firing mode at 300 rounds per minute, making it an incredibly deadly weapon system in close quarters environments. It can load a range of different cartridges, from pellets to slugs and even High Explosive fragmentation shells.

Key.Original: The Bulldog 12G is a bullpup 12-gauge pump-action shotgun that has two tube magazines which the user of the gun can switch between manually. Each tube holds up to eight 12-gauge shotshells. It also comes fitted with a rail that allows it to accept a variety of scopes.

Key.Original: The M4 Squad Semi-Automatic Shotgun (SSAS) is a gas-operated, rotating bolt, semi-automatic 12 gauge shotgun produced in Italy, and is capable of mounting a variety of accessories thanks to its modular design. It has seen widespread use in recent years, particularly in Europe, where it has gained notoriety for its use by military and police forces during the Rome Summer Riots.

Key.Original: The MP7 is a personal defense weapon (PDW) originating from Germany. It is chambered for the 4.6x30 mm cartridge, and maintains a high rate of fire. Its minimal weight, high rate of fire, and small dimensions make it a powerful weapon for CQC encounters.
